The game's about Style and the most famous factor of African Americans is their placement in the notorious gangs the Crips which are solely African American and the Bloods which are primarily African American - the two most famous gangs in the world and apart from these the only other factor of African Americans that are famous are their histories as Slaves - so when it comes to motifs that represent the style and culture of African Americans, beyond these there aren't many that would fit the game and I think that making a Champ that brings up the slavery is a bad idea.

I mean what else, culturally; fits an African American Champion more than a gangster theme or representation - apart from Slavery; and is still relevant to the kill or be killed reality of the game and the destruction it is based on?

If you look through history there aren't a lot of events or cultural prominences of a warrior or fighting based African American motif that could make its way into League, apart from traditional African tribal warriors and I think they wanted to move on from the spear Era to the current Gunslinging and Brutality of life and the world; even if a lot of it is a shadow of what is was recently: and I don't think they wanted Masai warriors or Somalian Gangsters or Pirates wielding Machetes so when it comes to African American theming, apart from the non African American related possibilities which are endless, putting a bit of culture into the game that is based on reality seems like a good move and was a current theme and not simply just an avoidance of any African American Theming at all wherein they could have just made all manner of skins for them they chose themes with similarities to the African American culture of today (even if a little less recent): The Crips and Bloods sweeping across America to become the most notorious gangs on the planet even to this day and a bit of one of the most recognized African American Cultures in the world (a Bandana donning Ekko) and some of the realities that came with this development of the African American culture in American Society (The most recognized and arguably powerful country in the world and a world leader) with Lucian's [Drive-by infamy].
